elements.content: Metal−organic framework-type Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53 have been characterized by solid-state NMR and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). 1H 2D double-quantum–single-quantum (DQ–SQ) magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR experiments unambiguously evidence two inequivalent water molecules in Al-MIL-53_np_H2O. A careful reinvestigation of the XRD structure of hydrated Al-MIL-53 proves, for the first time, the doubling of the unit cell supporting the presence of two inequivalent water molecules. One type of water molecule is located in the type A channel, interacting with the aromatic protons of framework organic moieties, whereas the other type of water molecule is in the type B channel far away from aromatic protons. Assignment of the corresponding 1H resonances to each water molecule was possible. 1H 1D MAS NMR leads to the same conclusion (i.e., two inequivalent water molecules) for the isostructural gallium-based material thanks to the positioning of the hydrogen atoms by Rietveld refinement. Moreover, when Ga-MIL-53 is prepared with fluorine in the synthesis medium (giving Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O), the situation is different. 2D 1H–13C heteronuclear correlation MAS NMR, high-field 1H DQ–SQ, and radio-frequency-driven recoupling MAS NMR indicate that only one type of water molecule is found in this material, in agreement with the structure.

One type of water molecule is located in the type A channel, interacting with the aromatic protons of framework organic moieties, whereas the other type of water molecule is in the type B channel far away from aromatic protons. Assignment of the corresponding 1H resonances to each water molecule was possible. 1H 1D MAS NMR leads to the same conclusion (i.e., two inequivalent water molecules) for the isostructural gallium-based material thanks to the positioning of the hydrogen atoms by Rietveld refinement. Moreover, when Ga-MIL-53 is prepared with fluorine in the synthesis medium (giving Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O), the situation is different. 2D 1H-13C heteronuclear correlation MAS NMR, high-field 1H DQ-SQ, and radio-frequency-driven recoupling MAS NMR indicate that only one type of water molecule is found in this material, in agreement with the structure.

elements.content: Among the porous materials, metal–organic framework (MOF)-type materials are very interesting owing to their hybrid and most often crystalline framework consisting of metal species connected by organic linkers. By choosing properly the metal and the organic linker, various topologies can be prepared, allowing fine tuning of the physicochemical properties of the resulting material. The MOFs are considered to be versatile porous materials for large potential applications such as drug storage/release, gas storage, separation, catalysis, and chemical sensing.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Among the porous materials, metal-organic framework (MOF)-type materials are very interesting owing to their hybrid and most often crystalline framework consisting of metal species connected by organic linkers. By choosing properly the metal and the organic linker, various topologies can be prepared, allowing fine tuning of the physicochemical properties of the resulting material. The MOFs are considered to be versatile porous materials for large potential applications such as drug storage/release, gas storage, separation, catalysis, and chemical sensing.

elements.content: MIL-53-type materials constitute one of the most studied and flourishing families of MOFs since they exist with various trivalent metals such as Al, Ga, Sc, Cr, Fe, V, .... The aluminum form of MIL-53 is particularly interesting since this structure is capable of reversibly adsorbing water molecules. The chemical stability of Al-MIL-53 appears to be intermediate between those of Cr-MIL-53 and V-MIL-47 toward acids, bases, and water, and the formation of a γ-Al(O)(OH) shell has been evidenced after water reflux. Nevertheless, the dehydrated form of Al-MIL-53 is remarkably stable upon heating until 500 °C, whereas Cr-MIL-53 or V-MIL-47 decomposes already at 350 °C. As for Ga-MIL-53, even if it seems to be less stable than the aluminum counterpart, it has been shown to be a more efficient and selective catalyst than H-BEA or H-MOR for the alkylation of biphenyl.

elements.content: One main difference between Al- and Ga-MIL-53 resides in the nature of the phase obtained after dehydration. Indeed, the removal of occluded water molecules from the aluminum hydrated form (Al-MIL-53_np_H2O; see Table and Figure b) leads to a dehydrated and large-pore phase (Al-MIL-53_lp_empty; see Figure a), in the same way as Cr-MIL-53, whereas, for the gallium counterpart containing a small amount of fluorine (Ga(OH,F)_MIL-53_np_H2O; see Figure g) or no fluorine (Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc; see Figure e), this process leads to a dehydrated and narrow-pore form (Ga-MIL-53_np_empty/Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_empty; see Figure d). As described recently, this difference observed experimentally between Al- and Ga/Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53 has been rationalized using quantum chemistry calculations. They suitably explain the higher np → lp transition temperature experimentally evidenced by variable-temperature X-ray diffraction (VT-XRD), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and FTIR in the 450–520 K range for Ga-MIL-53 versus the 150–325 K range for Al-MIL-53.

Even if Ga- and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53 present many similarities, it is worth noting that Ga_MIL-53_np_H2O_dc crystallizes with a doubling of the unit cell volume compared to Ga(OH,F)_MIL-53_np_H2O. The suffix “dc” is added to the name of the sample for highlighting the “double” unit cell. This difference might be related to the substitution of one OH group among ten by F (0.7 wt %) in the inorganic chain of Ga-MIL-53. The presence of fluorine may also make Ga(OH,F)_MIL-53_np_H2O, to some extent, a more hydrophobic material than Ga_MIL-53_np_H2O_dc since the number of water molecules per Ga is only 0.83 for the former and 1 for the latter. Moreover, whatever the structure of hydrated Ga(OH,F)- or Ga-MIL-53, we achieved complete structural refinement in a previous work and in the present work, including the positioning of all hydrogen atoms thanks to molecular modeling combined with the Rietveld methods.

The suffix "dc" is added to the name of the sample for highlighting the "double" unit cell. The presence of fluorine may also make Ga(OH,F)_MIL-53_np_H2O, to some extent, a more hydrophobic material than Ga_MIL-53_np_H2O_dc since the number of water molecules per Ga is only 0.83 for the former and 1 for the latter. elements.content: To clarify the hydrogen bond network in hydrated Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53, structural reinvestigation based on powder XRD (PXRD) data as well as 1D and 2D 1H magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR analyses was undertaken. These latter experiments already proved to be useful to fulfill this purpose in the particular case of MOFs (Al-MIL-100, MIL-121, ...) or functionalized Al-MIL-53.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details

Sample Preparation and Dehydration Conditions

All reagents and chemicals were used without any further purification. The metal sources, aluminum nitrate nonahydrate Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (99.99%) and gallium nitrate hydrate (99.99%), were purchased from Acros Organics and Strem Chemicals, respectively. The organic linker, terephthalic acid (H2BDC; 99%), was supplied by Fluka. The solvents, DMF (≥99%) and ethanol EtOH (≥99.8%), were provided by Sigma-Aldrich and VWR, respectively. Hydrated Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53 have been prepared as described in the literature.

elements.content:
The water contents were determined thanks to thermal analyses (Figure S1, ) and confirmed by the Rietveld refinements.

The dehydrated samples of Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53 were obtained from the corresponding hydrated material after treatment under reduced pressure (2 × 10–3 Torr) at 200 °C overnight. They were then transferred into a glovebox and packed in the corresponding rotor under argon.

The water contents were determined thanks to thermal analyses (Figure S1, ) and confirmed by the Rietveld refinements.

The dehydrated samples of Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53 were obtained from the corresponding hydrated material after treatment under reduced pressure (2 × 10-3 Torr) at 200 °C overnight. They were then transferred into a glovebox and packed in the corresponding rotor under argon.

elements.content: 1H–13C solid-state frequency-switched Lee–Goldburg (FSLG) heteronuclear correlation (HETCOR) NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE II 400WB spectrometer (B 0 = 9.4 T) operating at 100.64 MHz for 13C and 400.18 MHz for 1H. Samples were packed in a 2.5 mm cylindrical zirconia rotor and spun at a spinning frequency of 30 kHz. Experiments were performed with a proton π/2 pulse duration of 2.75 μs, a contact time of 500 μs, and a recycle delay of 8 s. Two-pulse phase modulation (TPPM) 1H decoupling was used during 13C acquisition, and an FSLG homonuclear 1H–1H decoupling field of 91 kHz was used during t 1 evolution. Calibration was performed by comparison with 1D 1H MAS NMR spectra of the same sample. 1H MAS and 2D double-quantum–single-quantum (DQ–SQ) NMR spectra were recorded on the same probe and spectrometer with a π/2 1H pulse duration of 2 μs. Two rotor cycles of BABA dipolar recoupling were used for both excitation and reconversion of double-quantum coherences. T 1 measurements on the different materials lead to recycling delays of 8 and 25 s for the hydrated and dehydrated materials, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State NMR Characterization

 1H-13C solid-state frequency-switched Lee-Goldburg (FSLG) heteronuclear correlation (HETCOR) NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE II 400WB spectrometer (B 0 = 9.4 T) operating at 100.64 MHz for 13C and 400.18 MHz for 1H. Samples were packed in a 2.5 mm cylindrical zirconia rotor and spun at a spinning frequency of 30 kHz. Experiments were performed with a proton π/2 pulse duration of 2.75 μs, a contact time of 500 μs, and a recycle delay of 8 s. Two-pulse phase modulation (TPPM) 1H decoupling was used during 13C acquisition, and an FSLG homonuclear 1H-1H decoupling field of 91 kHz was used during t 1 evolution. Calibration was performed by comparison with 1D 1H MAS NMR spectra of the same sample. 1H MAS and 2D double-quantum-single-quantum (DQ-SQ) NMR spectra were recorded on the same probe and spectrometer with a π/2 1H pulse duration of 2 μs. Two rotor cycles of BABA dipolar recoupling were used for both excitation and reconversion of double-quantum coherences. T 1 measurements on the different materials lead to recycling delays of 8 and 25 s for the hydrated and dehydrated materials, respectively.

elements.content: 1H MAS, 2D double-quantum–single-quantum (BABA) and radio-frequency-driven recoupling (RFDR) NMR spectra were also obtained on a Bruker AVANCE III 750 MHz WB spectrometer operating at 750.13 MHz. All spectra were recorded with a spinning frequency of 30 kHz, a π/2 1H pulse duration of 1.25 μs, and a recycle delay of 3 s. A series of eight presaturation scans at the beginning of each 2D experiment allowed steady-state magnetization to be reached. Two rotor cycles of BABA dipolar recoupling were used for both excitation and reconversion of double-quantum coherences. During the RFDR experiments, the homonuclear dipolar interaction is reintroduced thanks to rotor-synchronized π-pulses during variable mixing times (500 μs or 2 ms).
elements.clean_text: 1H MAS, 2D double-quantum-single-quantum (BABA) and radio-frequency-driven recoupling (RFDR) NMR spectra were also obtained on a Bruker AVANCE III 750 MHz WB spectrometer operating at 750.13 MHz. All spectra were recorded with a spinning frequency of 30 kHz, a π/2 1H pulse duration of 1.25 μs, and a recycle delay of 3 s. A series of eight presaturation scans at the beginning of each 2D experiment allowed steady-state magnetization to be reached. Two rotor cycles of BABA dipolar recoupling were used for both excitation and reconversion of double-quantum coherences. During the RFDR experiments, the homonuclear dipolar interaction is reintroduced thanks to rotor-synchronized π-pulses during variable mixing times (500 μs or 2 ms).

elements.content:
1H and 13C chemical shifts were referenced to tetramethylsilane (TMS). Fittings of the NMR spectra to extract the proportion of the corresponding species were performed with the DMfit software.

X-ray Diffraction

The same procedure was used for both compounds Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. The powder was transferred into a glass capillary (Mark-tube made of special glass, no. 14, outside diameter 0.3 mm, Hilgenberg Gmbh) for powder XRD analysis. Four scans were collected between 4° and 85° (2θ) (step 0.01°, time acquisition per step 150 s) on a STOE STADI-P diffractometer in Debye–Scherrer geometry, equipped with a linear position-sensitive detector (6° in 2θ) and employing Ge monochromated Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The four scans were added for better statistics on the collected data. The resulting powder X-ray diffraction patterns show well-resolved diffraction peaks which confirm a good crystallinity. All peaks were ticked and indexed with a monoclinic unit cell and refined in space group P21/c (No. 14) with a = 19.502(2) Å, b = 15.197(2) Å, c = 6.569(1) Å, β = 104.189(7)°, V = 1887.4(5) Å3, and FOM(30) = 29.9 (FOM = figure of merit) for Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and a = 19.680(3) Å, b = 7.6465(7) Å, c = 15.117(3) Å, β = 103.776(6)°, V = 1927.5(6) Å3, and FOM(30) = 41.4 for Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. The doubling of the unit cell parameter b of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc in comparison with that of the previous structural study by Loiseau et al. is here justified by additional weak but present peaks. The main ones of Miller indices (2,1,0) and (3,1,–2) are localized at 11.01° and 28.72° (2θ), respectively. It is worth noting that in the previous study the Rietveld refinement suffered from the probable presence of an impurity(ies) as illustrated in the Rietveld plot of hydrated Al-MIL-53 (MIL-53lt (Al)) reported in Figure 9c for which some ranges of data were subtracted and which can explain the choice of a normal b unit cell parameter of about 7.6 Å. The better FOM(30) value obtained here for Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc is due to a larger number of ticked peaks in the low-angle zone; e.g., the peaks of Miller indices (2,3,0) and (5,2,0) at 19.87° and 26.30° (2θ) are too weak in the case of hydrated Al-MIL-53 and not taken into account. These unit cell parameters and the space group deduced from the indexation routine are in accordance with those given for hydrated Ga-MIL-53 by Volkringer et al. This last structure was used as a starting model for the Rietveld refinement in both cases, which was performed with the GSAS package. For Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc, the gallium atoms were replaced by aluminum atoms. The missing hydroxide and water hydrogen atoms were computed from molecular modeling using the Cerius2 software. During the Rietveld refinement, all atoms were refined isotropically and soft restraints (bonds, angles, planars) were added to maintain a proper structure of the terephthalate ligands, water molecules, and hydroxide groups. The final Rietveld refinements gave excellent reliability factors; the final Rietveld plots are displayed in Figures S2 and S3 in the , and crystal as well as Rietveld refinement parameters are listed in Tables S1 and S2, respectively, in the . Figures S4 and S5 in the display the asymmetric unit of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. In Tables S3–S6 in the are listed atomic parameters and selected bond distances and angles. CIF files of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc can also be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, quoting deposition numbers CCDC 1007172 and CCDC 1007163, respectively.

The same procedure was used for both compounds Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. The powder was transferred into a glass capillary (Mark-tube made of special glass, no. 14, outside diameter 0.3 mm, Hilgenberg Gmbh) for powder XRD analysis. Four scans were collected between 4° and 85° (2θ) (step 0.01°, time acquisition per step 150 s) on a STOE STADI-P diffractometer in Debye-Scherrer geometry, equipped with a linear position-sensitive detector (6° in 2θ) and employing Ge monochromated Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The four scans were added for better statistics on the collected data. The resulting powder X-ray diffraction patterns show well-resolved diffraction peaks which confirm a good crystallinity. All peaks were ticked and indexed with a monoclinic unit cell and refined in space group P21/c (No. 14) with a = 19.502(2) Å, b = 15.197(2) Å, c = 6.569(1) Å, β = 104.189(7)°, V = 1887.4(5) Å3, and FOM(30) = 29.9 (FOM = figure of merit) for Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and a = 19.680(3) Å, b = 7.6465(7) Å, c = 15.117(3) Å, β = 103.776(6)°, V = 1927.5(6) Å3, and FOM(30) = 41.4 for Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. The doubling of the unit cell parameter b of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc in comparison with that of the previous structural study by Loiseau et al. is here justified by additional weak but present peaks. The main ones of Miller indices (2,1,0) and (3,1,-2) are localized at 11.01° and 28.72° (2θ), respectively. It is worth noting that in the previous study the Rietveld refinement suffered from the probable presence of an impurity(ies) as illustrated in the Rietveld plot of hydrated Al-MIL-53 (MIL-53lt (Al)) reported in Figure 9c for which some ranges of data were subtracted and which can explain the choice of a normal b unit cell parameter of about 7.6 Å. The better FOM(30) value obtained here for Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc is due to a larger number of ticked peaks in the low-angle zone; e.g., the peaks of Miller indices (2,3,0) and (5,2,0) at 19.87° and 26.30° (2θ) are too weak in the case of hydrated Al-MIL-53 and not taken into account. These unit cell parameters and the space group deduced from the indexation routine are in accordance with those given for hydrated Ga-MIL-53 by Volkringer et al. This last structure was used as a starting model for the Rietveld refinement in both cases, which was performed with the GSAS package. For Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc, the gallium atoms were replaced by aluminum atoms. The missing hydroxide and water hydrogen atoms were computed from molecular modeling using the Cerius2 software. During the Rietveld refinement, all atoms were refined isotropically and soft restraints (bonds, angles, planars) were added to maintain a proper structure of the terephthalate ligands, water molecules, and hydroxide groups. The final Rietveld refinements gave excellent reliability factors; the final Rietveld plots are displayed in Figures S2 and S3 in the , and crystal as well as Rietveld refinement parameters are listed in Tables S1 and S2, respectively, in the . Figures S4 and S5 in the  display the asymmetric unit of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. In Tables S3-S6 in the  are listed atomic parameters and selected bond distances and angles. CIF files of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc can also be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, quoting deposition numbers CCDC 1007172 and CCDC 1007163, respectively.

(see Table and Figure a,b). These authors also performed a multinuclear solid-state NMR study of the three forms of Al-MIL-53. In particular, 1H MAS NMR on the hydrated form (Al-MIL-53_np_H2O) evidenced three resonances at 1.7, 4.5, and 7.2 ppm corresponding to bridging Al–OH–Al, encapsulated water, and aromatic protons, respectively. An additional structural study was performed by the partial charges and hardness analysis (PACHA) method, leading to the positioning of H atoms and suggesting that the hydrogen atoms of water molecules preferentially interact with the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of the linker rather than with that of the bridging Al–OH–Al groups. elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc

The structures of as-synthesized, empty and large-pore as well as hydrated Al-MIL-53 have been solved without refinement of H atoms from powder XRD patterns by Loiseau et al. (see Table  and Figure a,b). These authors also performed a multinuclear solid-state NMR study of the three forms of Al-MIL-53. In particular, 1H MAS NMR on the hydrated form (Al-MIL-53_np_H2O) evidenced three resonances at 1.7, 4.5, and 7.2 ppm corresponding to bridging Al-OH-Al, encapsulated water, and aromatic protons, respectively. An additional structural study was performed by the partial charges and hardness analysis (PACHA) method, leading to the positioning of H atoms and suggesting that the hydrogen atoms of water molecules preferentially interact with the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of the linker rather than with that of the bridging Al-OH-Al groups. For the hydroxyl proton, two possibilities are envisaged: either it may be directed toward the water molecule and be involved in a strong hydrogen-bonding interaction or it may be directed toward the oxygen of the carboxylate group.

elements.content: In 2010, Lieder et al. studied the adsorption of various molecules (water, o-xylene, and nitrogen bases such as acetonitrile, ammonia, and pyridine) in Al-MIL-53 by 1H and 27Al MAS NMR. In the particular case of water adsorption, these authors obtained a 1H MAS NMR spectrum of Al-MIL-53_np_H2O similar to that obtained by Loiseau et al. with three resonances at 2.6, 5, and 7.2 ppm but mentioned for the first time that the decomposition of the three resonances does not match the proportions expected from the Al(OH)(BDC) H2O formula (where BDC = terephthalate = C8H4O4). Indeed, according to the assignment of the 1H lines, an area ratio of 1:2:4 is expected for the resonances at 2.6, 5, and 7.2 ppm, respectively, instead of the 2:1:4 ratio obtained experimentally. Lieder et al. suggest the existence of two nonequivalent water molecules even if the structure shows a single crystallographic site for the oxygen of water. One water molecule, detected at ∼5 ppm, interacts with the oxygen of the organic BDC linker, and the other one at 2.6 ppm also interacts with the same oxygen of the organic linker or with an O atom of a neighboring water molecule. In this latter case, the involved distances are greater, leading to a weaker hydrogen bond. Because the 1H chemical shift is known to strongly depend on the strength of the hydrogen bond, this explains the lower value of 2.6 ppm. Moreover, the splitting of the water signals into two resonances at 2.6 and 5.0 ppm suggests a rapid exchange between the different adsorbate states which is slow in comparison with the difference in their resonance frequencies. It is also worth noting that according to their results these authors suggest, like Loiseau et al., that H atoms of water molecules preferentially interact with carboxylate groups rather than with bridging Al–OH–Al groups.

elements.content: To assign those three resonances and gain some insight into the hydrogen bond network of water in Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc, a 1H 2D SQ–DQ MAS NMR experiment was performed. This experiment allows the spatial proximities between protons to be probed. Depending on the length of the double-quantum excitation and reconversion periods, short-range interactions (within a few angstroms) are probed. On the diagonal of the 2D spectrum, correlation between like spins is shown provided that the distance between the spins is short, whereas off-diagonal peaks indicate the spatial proximities between unlike spins. Because the purpose of the study concerned the existence of hydrogen bonds, short excitation and reconversion times of only two rotor periods were chosen. The 1H 2D SQ–DQ MAS NMR spectrum (Figure ) displays two autocorrelations at 2.7 and 7.4 ppm. The latter is easily assigned to the four aromatic protons according to the estimated intraorganic moiety distances of 2.41(3), 4.07(3), and 4.72(3) Å, whereas the shortest distances between intra- and interchain hydroxyl protons are 4.70(9) and 5.11(7) Å, respectively. Thus, the presence of an autocorrelation at 2.7 ppm suggests that this resonance also accounts for one water molecule as proposed by Lieder et al. Indeed, the intramolecular H···H distance in a water molecule is around 1.6(1) Å, explaining the observed relatively strong autocorrelation. Although less visible, the resonance at 5.5 ppm also has an autocorrelation as expected for water molecules. Therefore, we can conclude that the hydrated Al-MIL-53 contains two inequivalent water molecules inside the pores, although the structure determined from XRD only predicts one based on the oxygen atom location. Moreover, the absence of off-diagonal correlation between the resonance at 2.7 ppm and that at 7.4 ppm indicates that there are no spatial proximities between the aromatic and these water hydrogen atoms. Because aromatic protons are close to carboxylate moieties, a hydrogen bond between this water molecule and the carboxylate moieties is unlikely. Nevertheless, the existence of a weak hydrogen bond between hydrogen atoms of water molecules and the bridging hydroxyl (as expected from the structure) cannot be excluded. An off-diagonal peak between the resonances at 5.5 and 7.4 ppm is also visible even if it is poorly resolved (see Figure , horizontal solid line).

elements.content: Figure S6a in the shows a projection of the Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc structure along (001). As mentioned by Volkringer et al., in the case of hydrated Ga-MIL-53, two types of channels with a rhombus shape are present in Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc: type A in which the Ow1 water molecules are spaced outwardly from the b,c-plane passing through the small diagonal of the rhombus (blue dashed line in Figure S6a) and type B where the Ow2 water molecules are nearly coincident with the corresponding same plane (red dashed line in Figure S6a). This difference involves two different hydrogen-bonding schemes. From the bond distances shown in Figure S7a in the , it is clear that the water molecule Ow1 inside the A-type channels is at the origin of the off-diagonal peak between the resonances at 5.5 and 7.4 ppm observed in the 2D 1H DQ–SQ MAS NMR spectrum (see above). In fact, the distance between the water molecule hydrogen atom (Hw12) and the proton of framework organic moieties (H13) is 2.41(9) Å. The situation is different inside the B-type channels (Figure S7b) since the shortest distances (not shown) between the H atoms of water molecules and the aromatic protons are 3.11(10) and 3.42(9) Å for Hw21···H16 and Hw22···H23, respectively. As a consequence and as mentioned by Volkringer et al., on the basis of the O···O intermolecular distances in the case of hydrated Ga-MIL-53, inside B-type channels, the water molecules involving Ow2 form chains along the c-axis (Figure S7b). Inside A-type channels, due to the strong interaction between the aromatic protons H13 and the H atoms of water molecules involving Ow1, only pairs of water molecules are observable in Figure S7a, the shortest intermolecular distance between water molecule pairs being 3.39(12) Å (Hw12···Hw12, Figure S7a).

elements.content: The 1H MAS NMR spectrum of Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc displayed in Figure d exhibits at least two resonances at 3.0 and 7.0 ppm, the latter one being broad (∼980 Hz width at half-height) and asymmetric. Similar structures (with two types of channels) between hydrated phases of Al-MIL-53 and Ga-MIL-53 lead however to different 1H MAS NMR signatures (see Figure a,d). It is worth noting that the resonance at 5.5 ppm observed for Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc is not resolved in the case of the Ga counterpart despite the fact that both compounds are isostructural (double cell and two distinct water molecules). Decomposition of the signals indicates that the resonance at 3.0 ppm accounts for 27% of the total intensity whereas that at 7.0 ppm represents 73%. This supports the presence of two inequivalent water molecules distributed over two crystallographic sites as shown by the XRD data. One is associated with the resonance at 3.0 ppm and the other one with the resonance at 7.0 ppm. Indeed, by considering the asymmetric unit of Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc (Figure S5, ), the eight aromatic protons should represent 57.1%, the two hydroxyl protons 14.3%, and the four water protons 28.5% of the 1H NMR signal. Thus, the expected area ratio is 71.4% for the resonance at 7.0 ppm (eight aromatic and two water protons) and 28.6% (two hydroxyl and two water protons) for that at 3.0 ppm, which is very close to the experimental data. Unfortunately, because the water resonance is not resolved from that corresponding to aromatic protons, the 1H 2D SQ–DQ MAS NMR experiment (result not shown) does not allow further study of the hydrogen bonds in this material. Upon dehydration, the intensity of the resonance at 3.0 ppm decreases significantly (see Figure e), suggesting that this resonance accounts for both μ-OH and some water molecules in the hydrated sample in agreement with the assignment suggested above.

elements.content: The notable difference between the positions of the Ow2 water molecules in Al-MIL-53 and Ga-MIL-53 is probably related to the large difference in the acidity strength since the bridging μ-OH of gallium compounds exhibits a much stronger Brønsted-type acidity than the aluminum counterparts. As a consequence, both water molecules (associated with Ow1 and Ow2) are more attracted by the bridging hydroxyl group in Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc.

As a consequence, both water molecules (associated with Ow1 and Ow2) are more attracted by the bridging hydroxyl group in Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc.

elements.content: The 1H MAS NMR spectra of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_empty and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O are reported in parts b and c, respectively, of Figure . Only two resonances are detected for both materials at 3.2 and 7.2 ppm. Decomposition of the spectrum of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_empty leads to a 1:4 area ratio. Therefore, the resonance at 7.2 ppm is assigned to the four protons from BDC moieties, and that one at 3.2 ppm corresponds to the μ-OH bridging hydroxyls, in agreement with the formula. Moreover, this assignment is also consistent with the existing literature on materials containing μ-OH groups that shows that the 1H chemical shift of the hydroxyl proton is expected between −1.0 and +4.3 ppm.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O

The 1H MAS NMR spectra of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_empty and Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O are reported in parts b and c, respectively, of Figure . Only two resonances are detected for both materials at 3.2 and 7.2 ppm. Decomposition of the spectrum of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_empty leads to a 1:4 area ratio. Therefore, the resonance at 7.2 ppm is assigned to the four protons from BDC moieties, and that one at 3.2 ppm corresponds to the μ-OH bridging hydroxyls, in agreement with the formula. Moreover, this assignment is also consistent with the existing literature on materials containing μ-OH groups that shows that the 1H chemical shift of the hydroxyl proton is expected between -1.0 and +4.3 ppm.

elements.content: Despite the presence of water in Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O in addition to the protons of the organic linker as well as those of the bridging hydroxyls, only two resonances are observed on the 1H MAS NMR spectra of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O (see Figure c) as in the case of Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc (see Figure d). It is worth noting the significant increase of the intensity of the resonance at 3.2 ppm upon water adsorption (see Figure b,c) that accounts for 28% of the whole signal. Therefore, this resonance might correspond to one hydroxyl proton from μ-OH groups and two protons of water molecules even if in this case the expected area ratio should be 42.8%. Because the occupancy factor of the water molecule is 0.83 and about 10% of the hydroxyls are substituted by fluorine as determined by XRD and chemical analysis, respectively, the proportion is lowered to 39.0%. The difference from the NMR decomposition (11.0%) is too large to be attributed to the uncertainty of the decomposition. Because calorimetric measurements performed to study the effect of dehydration on Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O suggest that water molecules are not strongly hydrogen bonded to the surface of the material, a reasonable explanation would be a partial dehydration of the sample.

Because the occupancy factor of the water molecule is 0.83 and about 10% of the hydroxyls are substituted by fluorine as determined by XRD and chemical analysis, respectively, the proportion is lowered to 39.0%. The difference from the NMR decomposition (11.0%) is too large to be attributed to the uncertainty of the decomposition. Because calorimetric measurements performed to study the effect of dehydration on Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O suggest that water molecules are not strongly hydrogen bonded to the surface of the material, a reasonable explanation would be a partial dehydration of the sample.

elements.content: Another hypothesis would be a behavior similar to that observed for Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc, which contain two types of water molecules with distinct proton chemical shifts. Indeed, Volkringer et al. observed a 1H resonance at 7.5 ppm assigned to water protons interacting through a hydrogen bond with a bridging Al–OH–Al in MIL-118A, an aluminum-based MOF-type material. To improve the resolution of the 1H MAS NMR spectrum and attempt to highlight the resonance corresponding to water, 1H MAS NMR experiments were performed at high field (750 MHz). The result is shown in Figure . The resonance detected at 7.2 ppm at low field is split at high field into two resonances detected at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm. At this stage of the study one signal was expected to correspond to the aromatic hydrogen atoms and the other one to water. To assign these two resonances to the proper protons, a 1H–13C HETCOR was performed. In this experiment, the magnetization is transferred from 1H to 13C thanks to through-space dipolar coupling. Consequently, the spatial proximities that are also closely related to the interactions can be probed. A short contact time of 500 μs was chosen to select only very short distances (around one bond length) between protons and neighboring carbons. The result is shown in Figure . The F2 projection (13C) shows three resonances at 130.3, 136.6, and 175.6 ppm characteristic of CH aromatic groups, quaternary aromatic carbon, and carboxylate groups of BDC moieties, respectively. Despite the short contact time, all 13C resonances are correlated to both 1H resonances at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm, suggesting their assignment to aromatic protons. Note that the 1H resonance at 3.2 ppm is not detected in the F1 projection due to the short (500 μs) contact time. Thus, no correlation between this 1H resonance and carbons is observed, indicating that the involved distances are greater than one bond length. Indeed, according to the structure of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O and as shown in Figure S9a in the , the shortest distance between the hydroxyl proton H1 and a carbon of the organic linker is 3.53(2) Å (H1···C1), whereas the minimum distance measured between the water protons and the carbon atoms is 2.95(11) Å (Hw1···C1). Consequently, both 1H resonances detected at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm correspond to aromatic protons.

elements.content: Once the 1H resonances are assigned, it is possible to study the hydrogen bond network in the Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O structure. Such information will enable a better understanding of the role of these weak bonds in the breathing effect responsible for the original properties of some of MOFs and will also validate (or not) the proposed assignment. The high-field 1H 2D SQ–DQ MAS NMR spectrum (Figure ) displays two autocorrelations, an intense one at 3.2 ppm and a weak one at 7.0 ppm. Because of the short delay used for excitation and reconversion of DQ coherences, only short distances are probed. Thus, the intense autocorrelation detected at 3.2 ppm is consistent with water intramolecular and intermolecular spatial proximities (d intra(Hw1···Hw2) = 1.56(8) Å and d inter(Hw1···Hw2) = 2.66(7) Å; see Figure S9a in the ) but could also reflect the spatial proximities between hydroxyl and water protons (d(H1···Hw1) = 2.06(12) Å). The weak autocorrelation at 7.0 ppm probably corresponds to spatial proximities between aromatic protons since the distances between H3 and H5 and between H2 and H4 are only 2.45(2) Å (see Figure S9a). This suggests that the resonances corresponding to the aromatic protons H2, H3, H4, and H5 cannot be resolved. The only off-diagonal correlation detected is observed between the resonances at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm as expected from spatial proximities between aromatic H atoms. Nevertheless, the assignment of these resonances to the corresponding H atoms is not possible due to similar involved H···H distances.

This suggests that the resonances corresponding to the aromatic protons H2, H3, H4, and H5 cannot be resolved. The only off-diagonal correlation detected is observed between the resonances at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm as expected from spatial proximities between aromatic H atoms. Nevertheless, the assignment of these resonances to the corresponding H atoms is not possible due to similar involved H⋅⋅⋅H distances.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that no off-diagonal correlation is seen between water protons and the aromatics protons since, according to the structure, the shortest distance is 3.04(8) Å (Hw2···H3), which seems to be too large to be detected in this experiment.

elements.content: To probe longer distances (associated with weaker dipolar interaction), high-field 1H RFDR experiments were performed. The use of a short mixing time (500 μs) for the RFDR experiment (result not shown) leads to the same conclusion as the SQ–DQ MAS NMR experiment. Nevertheless, employing a longer mixing time (2 ms) allows detection of off-diagonal correlations between both resonances at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm and that at 3.2 ppm (Figure ). This is in agreement with both the assignment of the resonances proposed above and the crystallographic structure of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O. Indeed, the distance between hydroxyl proton H1 and H2 belonging to the organic linker is 2.98(5) Å, whereas the shortest distance between water and BDC moieties is d(Hw2···H3) = 3.04(8) Å (Figure S9a, ).
elements.clean_text: To probe longer distances (associated with weaker dipolar interaction), high-field 1H RFDR experiments were performed. The use of a short mixing time (500 μs) for the RFDR experiment (result not shown) leads to the same conclusion as the SQ-DQ MAS NMR experiment. Nevertheless, employing a longer mixing time (2 ms) allows detection of off-diagonal correlations between both resonances at 7.0 and 7.6 ppm and that at 3.2 ppm (Figure ). This is in agreement with both the assignment of the resonances proposed above and the crystallographic structure of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O. Indeed, the distance between hydroxyl proton H1 and H2 belonging to the organic linker is 2.98(5) Å, whereas the shortest distance between water and BDC moieties is d(Hw2⋅⋅⋅H3) = 3.04(8) Å (Figure S9a, ).

elements.content: Thus, only one type of water molecule is found in Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O as previously determined by the structure determination from X-ray analysis. Compared to Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc, this material seems to possess a slightly more hydrophobic character as proved by the partial dehydration observed between the PXRD and 1H MAS NMR studies. This experimental fact may be assigned to the presence of fluorine in the material. Also, it is interesting to note that, from Figure S9b in the , the hydrogen-bonding scheme present in the unique type of channel of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O is similar to that present in the A-type channel of Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc (Figure S8a, ) but with slightly shorter H···H distances in the case of the latter.
elements.clean_text: Thus, only one type of water molecule is found in Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O as previously determined by the structure determination from X-ray analysis. Compared to Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc, this material seems to possess a slightly more hydrophobic character as proved by the partial dehydration observed between the PXRD and 1H MAS NMR studies. This experimental fact may be assigned to the presence of fluorine in the material. Also, it is interesting to note that, from Figure S9b in the , the hydrogen-bonding scheme present in the unique type of channel of Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O is similar to that present in the A-type channel of Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc (Figure S8a, ) but with slightly shorter H⋅⋅⋅H distances in the case of the latter.

elements.content: In summary, MOF-type Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH, F)-MIL-53 have been characterized by solid-state NMR. The comparison of the 1H MAS NMR spectra of both hydrated and dehydrated compounds together with 2D 1H DQ–SQ MAS NMR spectra allows the assignment of the different proton resonances. Two inequivalent water molecules were evidenced in both hydrated Al- and Ga-MIL-53 by solid-state NMR. A careful powder X-ray diffraction data analysis of Al-MIL-53 proves a doubling of the unit cell, supporting the presence of two crystallographic inequivalent water molecules. One type of water molecule is located in A-type channels, interacting with the aromatic protons of the organic moieties, whereas the other type of water molecule is in B-type channels far away from these aromatic protons. A similar behavior is observed for Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. Both solid-state NMR spectroscopy and Rietveld analyses have shown for the first time a total correlation between short- and long-range order in Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, MOF-type Al-, Ga-, and Ga(OH, F)-MIL-53 have been characterized by solid-state NMR. The comparison of the 1H MAS NMR spectra of both hydrated and dehydrated compounds together with 2D 1H DQ-SQ MAS NMR spectra allows the assignment of the different proton resonances. Two inequivalent water molecules were evidenced in both hydrated Al- and Ga-MIL-53 by solid-state NMR. A careful powder X-ray diffraction data analysis of Al-MIL-53 proves a doubling of the unit cell, supporting the presence of two crystallographic inequivalent water molecules. One type of water molecule is located in A-type channels, interacting with the aromatic protons of the organic moieties, whereas the other type of water molecule is in B-type channels far away from these aromatic protons. A similar behavior is observed for Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc. Both solid-state NMR spectroscopy and Rietveld analyses have shown for the first time a total correlation between short- and long-range order in Al-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc and Ga-MIL-53_np_H2O_dc.

elements.content: Despite a similar 1H MAS NMR spectrum when Ga-MIL-53 is prepared with fluorine in the synthesis medium, leading to Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O, 2D 1H–13C HETCOR MAS, high-field 1H DQ–SQ, and RFDR MAS NMR indicate that only one type of water molecule is found, in agreement with the structure.
elements.clean_text: Despite a similar 1H MAS NMR spectrum when Ga-MIL-53 is prepared with fluorine in the synthesis medium, leading to Ga(OH,F)-MIL-53_np_H2O, 2D 1H-13C HETCOR MAS, high-field 1H DQ-SQ, and RFDR MAS NMR indicate that only one type of water molecule is found, in agreement with the structure.

metadata.title:
New Insights
into the Hydrogen Bond Network in Al-MIL-53 and Ga-MIL-53
